subject: Re: [junit] Strange request: examples of "beautiful" test code
msgSnippet: I like that better. The only problem I have with that is that I need to have generics to acomplish it. I ve never been on a project that could use java 1.5
messageBody:
I like that better. The only problem I have with that is that I need to have
generics to acomplish it. I've never been on a project that could use java
1.5 exclusively yet and I don't want to run my tests with a different JVM
than the rest of the code must work in.
I agree with you, you start seeing new options when you start thinking
differentely. I especially like how the constraints are applicable in so
many domains. Imagine if you only had assertXxxx methods, then these kind of
things would probably not be discovered so easily.

So to go back to the original post, I think
assertThat(actual, is.eq("expected");

or the jMock equvalent

assertThat(actual, eq("expected");

is beautiful and readable (but I know people who think that assertTrue(x) is
all that's needed)
/J

On 11/30/06, David Saff <saff@...> wrote:
>
> On 11/29/06, Joakim Ohlrogge <joakim.ohlrogge@...<joakim.ohlrogge%40gmail.com>>
> wrote:
> > public void testForException() {
> > expectThatExceptionThrown(is.instanceOf(SomeException.class));
> > something.doSomethingThatShouldThrowException();
> > }
>
> The longer you use JMock, the more you begin to think about all the
> things you can do by introducing object impostors. I've written this
> on a project recently:
>
> public void testForException() {
> assertThrownException(isA(SomeException.class
> )).when(something).doSomethingThatShouldThrowException();
> }
>
> This is still magic, but the magic is in the API, rather than the test
> runner. I'm genuinely curious if you, dear reader, like this better.
>
> Thanks,
>
> David Saff
>
>
